abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Wholesale Markets
            Project is rated as unsatisfactory. Rapid development of
            other competing large markets affected achievement of
            project outcome and objectives pertaining to sustainability.
            Lessons drawn from the project include: 1) The rapid
            development of contemporary private marketing
            infrastructure, notably supermarkets and discount
            wholesalers was not foreseen at the time that the project
            concept was created. 2) It should not be taken for granted
            that the clients, i.e. the traders and their customers, will
            flock to the new market, merely by its being there. 3)
            Legally binding agreements on enforcement of pertinent laws
            with respect to market operations should be entered into
            with national and local authorities. 4) Revenue of
            traditional wholesale markets, i.e. those whose activities
            are limited to trade in perishable agriculture products, is
            insufficient to support investments required, notably when
            the costs of contemporary requirements to fulfill sanitary
            and environmental considerations are taken into account. 5)
            As in any other business venture, the sustainability and
            development of a wholesale market depends to a large degree
            on the adaptive skills and creativity of its management. 6)
            Projects based on joint stock companies as their
            institutional structure are liable to exhibit all problems
            that are inherent in corporate structures.

5083417.trustfund:
TF029318-PHRD-WHOLESALE MARKET
            DEVELOPMENT PROJ.,TF034316-POLAND - WHOLESALE MARKET
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF033766-POLAND - WHOLESALE MARKET DEVELOPMENT,TF034318-POLAND - WHOLESALE MARKET
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Wholesale Markets Project aims
            to construct a commercially self-sustaining urban wholesale
            market for the greater Gdansk area, complete with attendant
            physical infrastructure. There are two components. The first
            component 1) builds a fruit and vegetable hall complete with
            buyers' walkways and a provisions hall; 2) builds a
            flower hall with open stalls and storage rooms; 3)
            constructs an office building for use by the PHCRS (Gdansk
            wholesale market company) administration, maintenance, and
            security staff; 4) constructs ancillary buildings composed
            of a canopy covering the road, a toll booth, an office where
            entry fees will be collected and departure checks carried
            out, and a weighbridge with an inspection pit and customs
            control point; 5) groundwork and infrastructure including
            all heavy earth moving, creation of parking lots,
            construction of the road to the main highway, and fencing as
            well as installation of on-site water, sewage, electricity,
            gas, and telecommunications; and 6) pre-start-up expenses,
            working capital, and any fees and charges during
            construction. The second component 1) sets up a surface
            water drainage system that includes pipework to the existing
            culvert and a treatment plant to treat vehicle spillage and
            surface water; and 2) installs pipelines to connect the
            sewage system and the drinking water system, and connects
            the wholesale market to a gas supply line as well as
            interfacing with the public electricity and
            telecommunications networks.

repnme.cdata!:
Poland - Gdansk Wholesale Market Project :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Wholesale Market Project will build
            a contemporary wholesale market for perishable foodstuff and
            flowers on the outskirts of Gdansk, complete with attendant
            infrastructure. This environmental assessment looked at 7
            areas and drew the following conclusions: a) ground, soil,
            and geologic assessment - no major environmental or
            resettlement problems; b) hydrological characteristics -
            possible problems due to area fragility and watershed
            proximity, mitigated by water quality maintenance and
            pre-treatment ponds and ditches; c) landscaping &
            cultural heritage - impacts mitigated by visual and specific
            measures during construction and operation; d) air &
            noise pollution - expected to be below legal standards,
            though noise levels will remain high due to increased
            traffic and equipment noises; e) land use development plans
            - the project is in accordance with the current land use
            plan; f) health & stress - mitigated by the construction
            of a direct access road to the site and a landscaped earthen
            dike bordering the residential area; and g) potential for
            birds to endanger air traffic - mitigated by closed refuse
            containers and a waste separation system.
